fetched_title: Moroccan Eggs with Harissa Yogurt | Feasting At Home
main_text_content: Moroccan Eggs ! Eggs are baked in the most mouthwatering lamb stew infused with Moroccan Spices, then topped with Harissa Yogurt. A delicious brunch recipe perfect for lazy Sundays, or serve it up for dinner! Either way the flavors will satisfy! Well, good morning, Moroccan Eggs! These babies are baked in the most delicious lamb stew infused with fragrant Moroccan spices, then topped with flavorful Harissa yogurt and fresh cilantro. A hearty, stick-to-your-bones kind of brunch, perfect for lazy Sundays. It’s based on a dish we experienced in Morocco a few years back and I had it tucked away for these colder months. It’s similar to this Shakshuka Recipe , but with the addition of ground lamb and a whisper of cinnamon . You may also enjoy this Sweet Potato Hash , made with similar North African flavors. It starts with ground lamb. This week I’m partnering with American Lamb to help celebrate Sunday Funday . (Enter to win free lamb and some great accessories!) When using American lamb, you’re supporting local producers and their families, not relying on lamb that’s being imported from around the world. American lamb is fresher in because it can be found locally, and travels less, and it’s available year-round. The flavorful Moroccan stew is made with ground lamb, onion, garlic, tomatoes and spinach and infused with Moroccan Spices! It smells heavenly! Once the lamb stew is done ( it only takes about 25 minutes) make little wells for where the eggs will go. Add the eggs, then place in a 375F oven. Bake until the whites are opaque leaving the yolks soft, about 8-10 minutes. When the eggs are done to your liking, scatter with fresh cilantro and sprinkle with Aleppo Chili flakes. Spoon a little harissa paste over top, or whip up this easy Harissa yogurt!   Add a few tablespoons harissa paste (either store-bought or homemade) to a 1/2 cup of plain yogurt! I hope you enjoy these Moroccan Eggs and let me know what you think in the comments below! main_html_content:
Moroccan Eggs! Eggs are baked in the most mouthwatering lamb stew infused with Moroccan Spices, then topped with Harissa Yogurt. A delicious brunch recipe perfect for lazy Sundays, or serve it up for dinner! Either way the flavors will satisfy! 

Well, good morning, Moroccan Eggs! These babies are baked in the most delicious lamb stew infused with fragrant Moroccan spices, then topped with flavorful Harissa yogurt and fresh cilantro. A hearty, stick-to-your-bones kind of brunch, perfect for lazy Sundays.

It’s based on a dish we experienced in Morocco a few years back and I had it tucked away for these colder months. It’s similar to this Shakshuka Recipe, but with the addition of ground lamb and a whisper of cinnamon.

You may also enjoy this Sweet Potato Hash, made with similar North African flavors.

It starts with ground lamb. This week I’m partnering with American Lamb to help celebrate Sunday Funday. (Enter to win free lamb and some great accessories!)

When using American lamb, you’re supporting local producers and their families, not relying on lamb that’s being imported from around the world. American lamb is fresher in because it can be found locally, and travels less, and it’s available year-round.

The flavorful Moroccan stew is made with ground lamb, onion, garlic, tomatoes and spinach and infused with Moroccan Spices!

It smells heavenly! Once the lamb stew is done ( it only takes about 25 minutes) make little wells for where the eggs will go.

Add the eggs, then place in a 375F oven.

Bake until the whites are opaque leaving the yolks soft, about 8-10 minutes.

When the eggs are done to your liking, scatter with fresh cilantro and sprinkle with Aleppo Chili flakes.

Spoon a little harissa paste over top, or whip up this easy Harissa yogurt!

 

Add a few tablespoons harissa paste (either store-bought or homemade) to a 1/2 cup of plain yogurt!

I hope you enjoy these Moroccan Eggs and let me know what you think in the comments below!

Breakfast Succotash with Poached Eggs and Herb Oil

Happy Weekend!

xoxo

Print

Moroccan Eggs with Lamb and Harissa yogurt

5 Stars 4 Stars 3 Stars 2 Stars 1 Star 5 from 6 reviews
  • Author: Sylvia Fountaine
  • Prep Time: 10
  • Cook Time: 30
  • Total Time: 40 minutes
  • Yield: 6
  • Category: Breakfast, brunch, egg recipes, lamb recipes
  • Method: baked
  • Cuisine: Moroccan
Print Recipe
Pin Recipe

Description

Moroccan Eggs! Eggs are baked in a flavorful lamb stew infused with Moroccan Spices, topped with Harissa Yogurt. A delicious breakfast or brunch recipe. #moroccanrecipes

Ingredients

Units
  • 1/2 teaspoon each: fennel seeds, cumin seeds, caraway seeds
  • 1/2 onion, diced
  • 4 garlic cloves, rough chopped
  • 1 lb ground American lamb
  • 1 teaspoon salt
  • 2 teaspoons smoked paprika
  • 2 teaspoons cumin
  • 1/2 teaspoon aleppo chili flakes (or regular chili flakes)
  • 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon
  • 14-ounce can fire-roasted tomatoes ( and juices) , diced
  • 1/4 cup water, more as needed
  • 2 cups chopped spinach ( fresh, or use one cup frozen)
  • 6 eggs
  • salt and pepper to taste

Garnish: aleppo chili flakes, cilantro leaves and harissa yogurt

Instructions

  1. Preheat oven to 375F
  2. Over medium heat, in a dry skillet toast the whole spices for 1-2 minutes, until fragrant and golden. Set aside.
  3. Heat oil in the skillet, over medium heat and add the onion, garlic and ground lamb, breaking it apart and saute until the lamb is cooked through ( about 8 minutes)  While it is sauteing add the salt, spices and whole spices. Add the tomatoes, spinach and water, cover and simmer on low heat for 10 minutes.
  4. Taste the stew and adjust the salt or spice level to your liking. If it seems dry add a little more water so it’s a little juicy and still warm.
  5. Make six “wells” into the stew with a back of a spoon ( see photo) and crack the eggs into the wells. Sprinkle eggs with salt and pepper and place in the oven.
  6. Bake 7-10 minutes, or until the egg whites are cooked through and opaque, but the yolks are still soft.
  7. While this is baking, mix the harissa paste with the yogurt to serve on the side ( or spoon over top). See notes.
  8. Garnish with the cilantro and sprinkle with Aleppo ( or chili flakes).

Notes

Harissa paste can be purchased at most grocery stores- or make your own here!

To make harissa yogurt, simply mix a few tablespoons of harissa paste into 1/2 cup plain yogurt. Start conservatively, add more to taste.

Nutrition

  • Serving Size:
  • Calories: 318
  • Sugar: 2.5 g
  • Sodium: 608 mg
  • Fat: 22.9 g
  • Saturated Fat: 9.3 g
  • Carbohydrates: 6.9 g
  • Fiber: 1.9 g
  • Protein: 19.8 g
  • Cholesterol: 241.3 mg

She currently lives in the Pacific Northwest and shares seasonal, healthy recipes along with tips and tricks from her home kitchen.

Heat oil in the skillet, over medium heat and add the onion, garlic and ground lamb, breaking it apart and saute until the lamb is cooked through ( about 8 minutes)  While it is sauteing add the salt, spices and whole spices. Taste the stew and adjust the salt or spice level to your liking. If it seems dry add a little more water so it’s a little juicy and still warm.
Make six “wells” into the stew with a back of a spoon ( see photo) and crack the eggs into the wells. Sprinkle eggs with salt and pepper and place in the oven.
Bake 7-10 minutes, or until the egg whites are cooked through and opaque, but the yolks are still soft.

Garnish with the cilantro and sprinkle with Aleppo ( or chili flakes).

review.reviewBody: Made this for my family. My dad refuses to eat lamb, so I used beef. And it was really delicious, too! The yogurth fit perfect. We ate bread to it. Thanks for this flavourful recipe!
Love this recipe! I went vegetarian and double the spinach and onion and left out the Lamb and it was amazing!

Oh how I loved this dish! Thank you so much for this. I am vegetarian and replaced the lamb by soy curls/TVP and the result was beyond my expectations. I can't believe how perfectly the different spices/harissa/flavors combined. Will be making this frequently from now on. :-) Hope you are keeping safe. Cheers from France

This was nothing short of amazing. I’m trying to eat less meat so I used Impossible Burger in place of Lamb. The flavors were outstanding. I can’t rave enough about this dish. It works on so many levels.

Excellent dish with deep flavors/ it was a big hit at family dinner! I’m not a huge lamb fan, so I wasn’t sure about this dish, but was inspired to try it after roasting some of my overabundant tomatoes. I nearly doubled the amount of the toasted whole spices and I used dry vermouth in place of the water. The harissa yogurt was an excellent side.
